channel.title: Application Tutor/Developer
channel.description:
Hey guys, I have recently decided I want to start creating apps for android and apple. I am very new at this type of programming (I know it uses Java but it's different from rsps's) Anyways, _Vain has really helped me start out with this by helping me found a couple programs I need, now my problem is the experience. I am hoping somebody who has some decent knowledge about Application coding will be willing to be my tutor, and eventually be by my side developing. I really hope one of you decides to take this exciting, long, and rewarding journey with me! Please either leave a response or private message me if you are interested.
Thanks!

item.title: Application Tutor/Developer
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“b00mz1029, post:25, topic:534175”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=652970.msg4375704#msg4375704 date=1381992724]
So you have no knowledge on the subject, yet you call people with knowledge of it “kids”? Doesn’t it embarrass you that kids can learn without help, but you can’t?
[/quote]

I could learn by myself, i just find it more fun to be taught. Reading long boring articles and watching videos is hard to get interested in. Have someone to interact with is, in my opinion, a better learning method.[/quote]

Then don’t be rude to people willing to help

Read full topic

item.title: Application Tutor/Developer
item.dc:creator: @b00mz1029 b00mz1029
item.description:
@b00mz1029 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:21, topic:534175”][quote author=b00mz1029 link=topic=652970.msg4375645#msg4375645 date=1381973097]

[quote author=hadesflames link=topic=652970.msg4375593#msg4375593 date=1381966940]

You can only use C# with Android if you use the Monodroid. Without that, you can’t use it (and Monodroid is not free)

Not true.

http://www.dot42.com/[/quote]

That looks pretty good but sadly it doesn’t support threading and presumably other features. App development is hard without thread access

My point wasn’t it’s the best alternative, my point was there is AN alternative.

I also stated that just sticking to native Java code was even better than any C# alternative.

Everybody please get off my thread unless your posting something related to the topic. This has nothing to do with my topic.

This is all related to your topic. Everything that’s been posted is about Android development. If you don’t want to read it and learn, then don’t.

This topic is not about Android development. It is about finding someone to be my partner and tutor PERSONALLY. Not from random kids who arent looking to help. Stop posting.
[/quote]that would technically be spoon feeding which we don’t really promote here.

you could try asking your friends or advertise it via your signature… but if you aren’t willing to make the effort into learning, who’s gonna help you?

there’s so many resources to use, and the api is well documented… just use some google…[/quote]

Im looking for someone to tutor me, not give me all the answers (which is spoonfeeding) and then eventually develop with me. Im not trying to start any arguments here guys.

Read full topic

You can only use C# with Android if you use the Monodroid. Without that, you can’t use it (and Monodroid is not free)

In any case, if you want to make Android apps, you should just use Java. Using anything other than Java is just…stupid…

http://developer.android.com/sdk/installing/studio.html

item.title: Application Tutor/Developer
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Kiryn, post:11, topic:534175”][quote author=Arcik link=topic=652970.msg4375477#msg4375477 date=1381942842]
What you smoking?
[/quote]

How about instead of posting something negative explain why you’re being negative.

C# http://prntscr.com/1xpx1l

[code]package com.example.androidexample;

import android.os.Bundle;
import android.app.Activity;
import android.view.Menu;

public class MainActivity extends Activity
{

protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) 
{
	super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
	setContentView(R.layout.activity_main);
}

public boolean onCreateOptionsMenu(Menu menu) 
{
	// Inflate the menu; this adds items to the action bar if it is present.
	getMenuInflater().inflate(R.menu.main, menu);
	return true;
}

}
[/code]

Java http://prntscr.com/1xpyj2

[code]import java.awt.Frame;
import java.awt.Graphics;

@SuppressWarnings(“serial”)
public class Gui extends Frame
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
Gui m = new Gui();
m.createFrame();

}

public void createFrame()
{
	setTitle("JavaExample");
	setSize(765, 500);
	setVisible(true);
}

public void paint(Graphics g)
{
	g.drawString("Hello World!", 765/2, 500/2);
}

}
[/code]

The syntax is basically the same :|[/quote]

They’re both Java code examples you showed. What point are you trying to make?

Read full topic

item.title: Application Tutor/Developer
item.dc:creator: @Kiryn Kiryn
item.description:
@Kiryn wrote:

What you smoking?

How about instead of posting something negative explain why you’re being negative.

C# http://prntscr.com/1xpx1l

[code]package com.example.androidexample;

import android.os.Bundle;
import android.app.Activity;
import android.view.Menu;

public class MainActivity extends Activity
{

protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) 
{
	super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
	setContentView(R.layout.activity_main);
}

public boolean onCreateOptionsMenu(Menu menu) 
{
	// Inflate the menu; this adds items to the action bar if it is present.
	getMenuInflater().inflate(R.menu.main, menu);
	return true;
}

}
[/code]

Java http://prntscr.com/1xpyj2

[code]import java.awt.Frame;
import java.awt.Graphics;

@SuppressWarnings(“serial”)
public class Gui extends Frame
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
Gui m = new Gui();
m.createFrame();

}

public void createFrame()
{
	setTitle("JavaExample");
	setSize(765, 500);
	setVisible(true);
}

public void paint(Graphics g)
{
	g.drawString("Hello World!", 765/2, 500/2);
}

}
[/code]

The syntax is basically the same

Read full topic
